title: 106_hr5479
content:
The Act is titled the "Wholesale Motor Fuel Fairness and Competition Restoration Act." The Congress finds that various unfair and anticompetitive practices by oil companies contribute to unjustified retail motor fuel prices charged to American consumers, including price zoning, redlining, discriminatory pricing, and hidden cost allocation. Unfair practices by oil companies include price zoning, redlining, discriminatory pricing, and hidden cost allocation, all contributing to unjustified retail motor fuel prices. Price zoning artificially increases or depresses prices based on location, redlining restricts sales to certain distributors or markets, and discriminatory pricing is based on purchaser relationship and competition level. The oil companies engage in discriminatory pricing practices, using complex cost allocations to hide factors influencing wholesale prices. This allows them to charge different prices to various types of retailers in the same community, distorting the true wholesale price. It is necessary for the Federal Government to address these unfair practices. The Federal Government should prohibit unfair oil company practices in cost, pricing, and marketing to restore fair competition in the wholesale fuel market and empower consumers to understand price changes at the pump. Price discrimination prohibition. The Act prohibits terminal facilities from selling motor fuel to distributors or retailers at a higher price than what they charge others, with exceptions for pre-existing contracts. Price determination is based on regulations issued under the Act. The Act prohibits unfair pricing practices for motor fuel sales, with exceptions for existing contracts. The Federal Trade Commission can impose civil penalties up to $1,000,000 for violations, and criminal penalties include fines or up to 5 years in prison. This section will be effective 6 months after the Act's enactment. SEC. 4. FULL DISCLOSURE. The Federal Trade Commission, in consultation with the Secretary of Energy, will issue regulations requiring full disclosure by refiners and distributors of their wholesale motor fuel pricing policies. This includes rebates, incentives, and market enhancement allowances. The regulations will also establish procedures for determining the price charged by terminal facilities to distributors or retailers. The regulations will take effect 6 months after the enactment of this Act, and all information acquired will be made available to the public, except for protected trade secrets and commercial or financial information. The information disclosed under the Freedom of Information Act may be disseminated through the Energy Information Administration. SEC. 5. OWNERSHIP STUDY AND REPORT.

Within 18 months of this Act's enactment, the Federal Trade Commission, with input from the Secretary of Energy, must submit a report to Congress on whether a refiner owning or operating a retail fuel facility affects fuel prices. The report will also suggest any necessary legislative or administrative actions.

SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS.

Terms in this Act will follow definitions in the Petroleum Marketing Practices Act.
